results.title: The Mediterranean
results.creator_credit: Tom Naughton, Christopher Bryson, Joe Wiecha, Marianna Edmunds, Bertand Morin, Nicolas Valcour, Learning Channel, Quai 32 and New Dominion Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Archaeology”.
John Rhys-Davis narrates five excellent episodes which showcases archaeological exploration around the Mediterranean. French divers discover a cave filled with 18,000 year old rock paintings in “A Cave beneath the sea.” The Minoan colony of the island of Thera is shown in “Lost city of the Aegean.” The daily life of ancient Egypt is unlocked in “Forgotten mummies.” After World War 2, Schliemann’s discoveries at Troy, disappeared and the mystery is investigated in “Lost treasures of Troy.” The secret rituals of the women of Lesbos in Ancient Greece is the subject of the final episode entitled “Women of Lesbos.”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tom Naughton, Christopher Bryson, Joe Wiecha, Marianna Edmunds, Bertand Morin, Nicolas Valcour, Learning Channel, Quai 32 and New Dominion Pictures

results.title: Pre set tooling and automatic control
results.creator_credit: Peter Riding, Humphrey Barron and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Approaching Automation”.
Adapted metal cutting machines can greatly improve quality control, reduce scrap, decrease operator fatigue, and generally allow labour to be used more efficiently. Dealing with the use of a capstan lathe it is proposed that a job should be able to be rest before t becomes necessary. Problems of suing hie method are discussed and types pf controls available for particular jobs including fluid logic and pneumatic circuitry.

results.title: Design for assembly
results.creator_credit: Peter Riding, Humphrey Barron and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Approaching Automation”.
Discusses ways of increasing productivity by means of (1) design liaison with production engineers and sales personnel and, (2) low-cost automating techniques for small and medium batch assembly lines. Industrialists, engineers and consultants are interviewed to show the lessons that can be learned from their experiences.

results.title: Cutting of materials
results.creator_credit: Peter Riding, Humphrey Barron and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Approaching Automation”.
This film deals with the cutting of materials, using cutting, milling, drilling, turning. facing and threading machinery. Points out the advantages of pneumatic and electrical equipment over manual labour. Questions the applicability of some methods of cutting in use and sums up the benefits of part and full automation of existing plant.

results.title: Forming, feeding and assembly
results.creator_credit: Peter Riding, Humphrey Barron and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Approaching Automation”.
Discusses various means of adapting existing equipment, by adding to it or redesigning it. Much manual work can be cut down by installing timing devices and automatic controls, improving feeding methods and reassessing assembly procedures. Shows new methods of mechanical fastening, including the new adhesives. Stresses need to adhere to International and British Standards.

results.title: Another day, another dollar: three short films about the history of work
results.brief_description:
“Projected memories: work in old films”: In 1947, a projectionist took a collection of instructional 16mm films about work to the bush. This short film includes excerpts from that collection covering early footage (1900s-1930s) of families on the land; factory workers; steel workers; coal miners; working women; the rise of trade-unions and the 8-hour day; peace campaign of 1938; the invention of the teleprinter; the arrival of the corner grocer shop and much more.
“Never done: women, work and history”: Focuses on women in the workplace from the mid-1800s through to the 1970s including footage of the first women’s union (1882); industrialisation and factory work; the birth of the modern office worker (1890s); equal pay for equal work movement; WWI and WWII women in the workforce; trade-unionism and feminism.
“Close to slavery: black work in white history”: It was government policy for Aboriginal Australians to assimilate to the white ethics of education and work whereas traditional Aborigines did not recognise the western idea of work and preferred to follow their own cultural identity. Then came the mission stations, removal of Aboriginal children, forced labour often in the most deplorable conditions, exploitation and even when black Australians were trained in skilled work through the mission stations, white Australians would not employ them - all this most comprehensively portrayed by the archival footage in this film.
